title: injury marrs shinty return as newtonmore defender requires surgery after blow to the
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineFowler appeared to be knocked out after taking a blow to the head in the closing seconds of the game.The injury would require surgery in Aberdeen on Sunday morning, after the player was transfered from Raigmore in Inverness on Saturday evening. An update on the player#s condition # which suggested he suffered a skull fracture # was shared on the Newtonmore Camanachd Facebook site on Sunday afternoon.Fowler had helped his team to a - victory over last year#s Camanachd and MacTavish Cup winners.Iain Robinson got the opening goal after  minutes, rling in at the back post after a corner from the impressive winger Drew MacDonald.Jordan Fraser swept home a Keith MacRae cross to level matters on  minutes, but Max Campbell restored the visitors# lead in the nd minute, and veteran Fraser MacKintosh netted from long range just before half time to put Newtonmore # who were without Mike Russell and Craig Ritchie due to Covid # in command.The lack of pre-season action looked as though it had taken its toll, and Shiel never found their rhythm in a fragmented second half interupted by injuries.#More attacker Iain Robinson suffered a dislocated shoulder, a back problem forced off Shiel striker John MacRae, while defender David Falconer#s afternoon was ended early by a hamstring problem.Kinlochshiel manager Johnston Gill said: #We never reached half the level we did last season, and against a team like Newtonmore that isn#t enough.#We can play better, and we will play better as we get more games under our belts, but it#s a disappointing start to lose at home.#Newtonmore co-manager Norman MacArthur was delighted at his team#s display # with Steven MacDonald and Rory Kennedy outstanding in defence.He said: #We came over with no expectations # but the young boys who came in were fantastic. To get our season underway with a win at the Scottish champions is a great way to start.#ELSEWHERE ON SATURDAY, Mowi Premier League champions Kingussie got off to a flyer with Savio Genini scoring four in a - home rout of Caberfeidh.Lovat and Oban Camanachd each recorded - away wins at Kilmallie and Glasgow Mid Argyll respectively, while Kyles Athletic recovered from two down to salvage a - draw with Fort William at An Aird.In the National Division Skye Camanachd fell behind to a Daniel MacMillan strike after  minutes, but goals from Jordan Murchison on  and John Gillies on  minutes proved enoough to earn the islanders victory against Oban Celtic.Euan MacCormick scored four as Beauly set the pace in the ision by putting nine without reply past Aberdour.Lochaber edged Strathglass by the odd goal in five at Cannich, while Inveraray and Glenurquhart shared the points after a - draw at the Winterton.

title: hair it goes give ronny your support with charity fundsraiser
story: IT’S been a long time since Ronny McFall had his hair cut - and he just can’t wait for the big chop!In fact it has been almost two years since Harryville man Ronny, a familiar figure to many in his role as Tesco Community Champion, heard the snip of a barber’s scissors.But he’ll be going right back to zero next week when he has his head shaved to raise vital funds for a men’s homeless shelter in Ballymena. And you can show your support for a guy who has been a staunch backer of dozens of local community efforts in recent years by making a donation to boost that fundraising effort.Ronny explains: “Friday th March  was the last time I had my hair cut and the first lockdown started the following Monday.“I had been getting my hair cut to a Zero for over  years so everybody was used to seeing me close shaved.“After a few weeks on Social Media I started to friends posting pictures and videos of their DIY hair cuts, these were often cut by their children with funny results. “And, says Ronny, that is when he hit on his idea to ‘let it grow’ for a local cause.“I wanted to support a charity or community group which had operated all the way through these last two years. “I put a post-up on Facebook telling those who follow my Tesco Community work what my plan was and asked them to suggest a group. “The plan was to get it cut on the st anniversary of my last cut but this was not to happen as hairdressers could not operate at that time last year. “Ronny made the decision to grow it for another year - and he has been drip feeding social media with updates ever since.“Recently I put all the names of the suggested groups into a draw for my store manager Sam Larkin to pick one out. “It was videoed and was posted on Facebook. The lucky group was Lighthouse Hostel which is marking  years operating in Ballymena.”Ronny will finally get his long awaited shave from Santina McWilliams of Joes Barbers sometime during the mid-afternoon of Sunday th March - and he’d love to see his friends and supporters there.“I’ll be glad to get back to zero,” says Ronny. “But hopefully we will be able to raise a good sum of money for this worthwhile cause.“ The hostel recently created an online donation service, link here - https:lighthousehostel.org donation  “We will also be collecting in-store this Saturday and on Friday, Saturday and Sunday of next weekendanyone wants to donate in person.”

title: ian trevithick tributes paid to former belfast telegraph photographer
story: Award winner Ian Trevithick. Credit: Alan LewisIan TrevithickIrish Dancing World Championships  held at Waterfront Hall Belfast. Picture by Ian Trevithick FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueAward winner Ian Trevithick. Credit: Alan LewisStaff ReporterMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailTributes have been paid to award-winning former Belfastphotographer Ian Trevithick, described by friends as a lensman “of the highest calibre who had an expert eye”.Ian, who passed away yesterday , had courageously lived with a serious condition for some time.The winner of multiple Photographer of the Year awards over the years, friends often called him ‘Ian Terric’.Alan Lewis of the Northern Ireland Press Photographers Associationhad known Ian, from Blackskull in Co Down, for  years.Alan revealed how Ian had found a dog several years ago and took it to police in the hope it could be reunited with its owner. The officers didn’t really know what to do with the dog, said Alan, and so Ian askedhe could look after it until the owner was found. “They never found an owner, and Ian became devoted to the dog,” he said. “It just typied the type of guy he was.”He added: “As a person he was a gem to deal with. He was such a genuinely lovely fellow. If he could help you, or give you a lt, or had bother with anything at all, he was the first to extend a hand of friendship.”That dedication was also apparent in Ian’s fundraising work for Multiple Sclerosis charities. “He never let what befell him get him down. It was just typical of the man.”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Alan spoke of how the two of them had been assigned to the same job, covering a Irish dancing world championship in Belfast, at which Ian produced some of his most outstanding work. The dancers he framed, silhouetted against the lights of the Waterfront Hall, “stood out, and was typical of the type of work he would produce”.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseIrish Dancing World Championships  held at Waterfront Hall Belfast. Picture by Ian Trevithick FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueIrish Dancing World Championships  held at Waterfront Hall Belfast. Picture by Ian Trevithick“He was right at the top end of photographers, and certainly he was a great asset to the Belfastand our association.”NIPPA chairman Liam McBurney extended the organisation’s “deepest sympathy and condolences to the family of Ian Trevithick former staff photographer at the Belfast ”.“Ian was a multi-award-winning photographer of the highest calibre who had an expert eye. He was a true gentleman and will be sadly missed. “Former Belfastpictures editor Pete Rainey said he had been deeply saddened to learn of Ian’s passing. He described him as “a talented photographer who was always willing to help. Ian will be missed by his colleagues past and present”.
