title: dating app bumble launches new campaign help change relationship behaviours
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe romance gap, a term coined by Bumble, is a term for the disparity between men and women and our expectations of the genders when it comes to relationships and dating.% of respondents believed men are still expected to make the first move, according to a YouGov poll that was commissioned by Bumble.Almost  in  people in the UKsaid they expect men to take the lead but only % expected the same from women.Bumbles latest research suggests that daters want a very dferent kind of relationship dynamic.% of Brits say that equality is important between people who are dating or in a relationship.Meanwhile, % of respondents said that there are dferent expectations and expected behaviours depending on your gender when it comes to relationships.                                                                                                            :  Best Dating Sites in the UK to Find that Special Someone: Tinder is introducing a new security feature for users - is it coming to the UK                                                                                                            In other words, an overwhelming majority believe that there is a romance gap and that there are pressures for men and women to act a certain way.The dating app recognises that we have made "positive strides towards equality, traditional gender roles and expectations are still very present, and even, accepted in dating".In fact, some behaviours that we deem romantic for men are viewed negativelythey come from a woman.The research, which collected responses from across Europe, found that:.removeMen are still expected to take the lead: Over half of peoplestate that society expects men to take the lead in relationships, rising to almost  in  in the UK , whilst a mere % think society expects women to do so. For men, just over  in feel pressured to take the lead.Women should not appear desperate: In the UK, more than halfstate women are expected to avoid appearing too keen, clingy, attached or desperate. Interestingly this is felt signicantly more by womenthan men .Men worry about their lack of experience between the sheets: Nearly a fthof British men are concerned about being judged for their lack of sexual experience. Almost the same amount of womenfear they’ll be judged for the opposite - their number of intimate encounters. Women have a ‘shelf-le’ in dating: % state that women are expected to prioritise finding a relationship and settle down before they are ‘too old’. In contrast, only % say that society expects this of men. For women,  in have felt pressure to compromise on what they want while dating or in relationships. Men are expected to be the breadwinners: In the UK,  in say men are expected to earn more money and be responsible for finances, with only % agreeing this is expected of women.  in women have felt concerned of being judged for earning more than their partner. Women are changing their behaviour: Amidst all these expectations, it’s no surprise that  in women have changed their behaviour to make someone feel more powerful or comfortable. A couple on a date. Credit: Canva The new campaign forms part of Bumble’s efforts to empower people to create healthy and equitable relationships and combat "outdated" gender dynamics.“The Romance Gap is a new term, but many of us will know the feeling. Those moments of questioningsending that text makes you appear too keen, waiting for them to take the lead, or worryingyou are being judged for being too keen, too inexperienced, too old. At Bumble, we are focused on creating an app that empowers women to make the first move and date on their own terms from the beginning. But we alone cannot change societal expectations," Naomi Walkland, Bumble’s VP for Europe said.Ms Walkland continued: “An unexamined Romance Gap limits us, with  in  people agreeing that it makes it dficult to build equal relationships. The only way to reduce the Romance Gap is to acknowledge it exists and start an open conversation about how it impacts how we see ourselves, our partners, and relationships. Only when we are aware of it can we challenge each other to do away with gendered expectations of who should do what.”Its not just that the outdated genre dynamics are bad for equality, they stop us from making genuine connections with people, the dating app believes.According to its research, % say the impact of gender roles makes people behave in a way that is less true to who they are.It does appear though that change is on its way with % of respondents believing that in an ideal world we would not have expectations on who earns more, a more successful career , or who makes the first move by initiating a date .You can see the rest of Bumbles research, campaign and tips on striking up a conversation via the Bumble website.

title: thought for the week tom crean irelands antarctic hero
story: Police appeal after Lisburn hit-and-run   Oil price: Cheapest places in Northern Ireland for home heating oil revealedNewsCoronavirusTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsHealthBusinessEducationPeopleEnvironmentRead ThisUkraine CrisisFootballIrish League FootballSportMotorcyclingIce HockeyOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleFood and DrinkTravelHomes and GardensCars FamilyYour NIRetroOpinionAdvertise My BusinessNewsTom Crean Antarctic heroIn a week of dark and depressing news, there was one shaft of light.By The NewsroomMonday, th March , : am  "       "  An expedition to find the wreck of Sir Ernest Shackleton’s ship ‘Endurance’, long lost in Antarctic ice, successfully located the vessel, wondrously preserved , metres deep.When ‘Endurance’ was trapped in ice in , the crew managed to travel in three small boats to nearby Elephant island. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.From there, Shackleton and two others sailed across  miles in an open boat, in some of the worst weather in the world, before arriving in South Georgia and raising the alarm. Rev David ClarkeThe help they obtained there led to the successful rescue of the entire crew. Central to that mission was the heroic Tom Crean, from Anaschaul in Kerry’s Dingle peninsula.Tom Crean was an accidental polar explorer. He had joined the Royal Navy and  found himself on naval duties in New Zealand. At that time, Captain Robert Falcon Scott’s ship ‘Discovery’ was heading south on a reconnaissance mission. While docked for repairs in New Zealand, a member of Scott’s crew deserted and the Captain saw in Crean some of the qualities needed for the arduous challenges ahead. Some years later Crean was among the party that accompanied Scott on his ill-fated expedition to the South Pole, although he was not chosen to form part of the group for the last push to the Pole. Scott, of course, discovered that the Norwegian Amundsen had got there first. When Scott’swas delayed, Crean led the group that found Scott and his colleagues dead in their tents.When Shackleton came to make his own expedition he already knew the admirable qualities of the Kerryman. Even after their terrying voyage in mountainous seas to arrive on South Georgia, these seamen had to become mountaineers, for they discovered they had to cross a mountain range over , feet high to get to the whaling station. When they eventually arrived, they were barely recognisable as human beings.When Shackleton came to write of that episode he recorded that he had the strange feeling that there were not three men on that journey, but four. He said nothing to the other two, but one of them remarked to him, ‘Boss, I had the curious feeling on the march that there was another person with us.’ And apparently the third man said the same thing.The Old Testament book of Psalms includes a cluster of ‘Songs of Ascents’, songs sung by pilgrims ascending to Jerusalem for Passover. The most famous of them celebrates God’scare, and includes the promise, ‘The sun will not harm you by day nor the moon by night’. The peril of sunstroke in the blistering sun is obvious enough, but the reference to the moon may refer to mental distress, for it is from the word for moon that we derive the word ‘lunacy’. In any event, the reference is to God’s comprehensive care, by day and night.
